So last week you talked about Father Emil. Father Emil. That's right. And so we're kind of stringing along a series of podcasts that seem related because this week we're talking about. War. War. And just war at that. So kind of an interesting hot topic, I guess, because especially with the war in Iraq, there was a lot of debate between faithful Orthodox Catholics about whether or not the preemptive strike, the preemptive war we launched on Iraq was a just war in the sense of the Catholic traditions, a sense of just war or not. And there were good faithful Catholics on both sides of the argument. And it's still... I don't know. A lot of those tensions, I think, are still being carried into because we're still dealing with the effects of that war and then other wars with terror and stuff like that. One of the good signs, I actually think, is that we seem to get in trouble with everybody. Yeah. Everybody seems to get angry at one of these positions on these podcasts. It's true. Including Capital Punishment, which we'll get some feedback for that. I'm sure. But it's the same thing with every other topic. I'm sure. So I'm going to try as best I can to not present Joe Doman's understanding of just war. Dr. Bruegers. Dr. Bruegers. He's a moral theology professor. No, a lot of what I'm going to talk about is actually straight out of the Catechism, and then we're just going to talk about it and maybe apply it to the situation 10 years ago when we went to war in Iraq. And we won't go into depth in that, but at least how would you apply these principles to that situation? Gotcha. So anyway, here we go. So there's basically in the Catechism, the just war tradition goes back to St. Augustine talks about it in his City of God. Aquinas talks about just war. So it's been something that's been in the tradition for a long time, that war is a necessary evil that humanity always finds itself in. But it's not like, you know, you've heard that phrase, all is fair in love and war. Well, it's really not true. Like, all is not moral in war. Like, there's still a moral realm, and you can go to war for unjust reasons, but you can also conduct a war in an unjust way. So even the idea of a just war, what do we mean when we say that? That implies that there are... situations which arise where some injustice has been committed to which war is the only appropriate response. So having a just war implies an injustice, a grave injustice that's done. And the only necessary, the only... appropriate response to the injustice is war. Exactly. Gotcha. So the state rightly goes to war when doing so constitutes the best available remedy for righting the injustice that was caused in the first place. Gotcha. So when we talk about just war, it's always, you're always speaking about just war when there's an injustice already present that has to be remedied. Which I think is pretty radical, actually. I mean, just the thought that war has to be justified. I mean, who talks like that outside of the Catholic Church? I mean, it's just kind of there's so many other different kind of dimensions and intentions and purposes behind it. It's just like this is a justified response to remedy injustice. Right. And so like war is always This is tricky because hot language we can get tripped up on. War is always an evil. It's not always a moral evil. Like, we're not always morally culpable to stand before God if we're going into war justly. But it's always an evil in the sense of it's a grave deprivation of a good. You know, people are dying. It's not a moral evil, but it's an evil in the sense of there's a good that's being destroyed. And that's always an evil, even though it might not be a moral choice where I'm choosing evil. Does that make any sense? Yes, of course. I think it's important because... War is just good to get them. I said that you can have a just war. That is a moral war. But war. in the fact that it's war, it's always an evil. Right. In a sense, it's not something that's desired for its own sake. Right. So, that's important. So, anyway, the Catechism pretty much deals with this in the 23 zeros of the Catechism. So, if you go to those paragraphs, this is where you'll find the just war stuff. And there's two senses of it. They call it the ius ad bellum, which is the justice to go to war, to go to bellum as war, and then the ius in bello, the justice. in war. So there's two ways they speak about, you know, how do you, how do you make a just choice to go to war? And then when you're in war, how do you Oh, that's interesting. Because, yeah, we often think of just war theory as just the decision to go to war, but it's actually... Once you're in the war... There's a just... There's a whole evaluation, moral evaluation that has to happen within the war of how you actually... Exactly. It's not like once you're... Okay, we've gone to war and now everything's fair. We just got to win this war. Yeah. Exactly. Like there is grave injustices that can be committed and have been throughout history in war. So there's five main... main kind of elements to the use ad bellum, the decision to go to war justly. And so this is laid out in the Catechism starting in, I think, 23.7. So the first one is a presumption against war. And this is something that's kind of debated against. But I'll just read you what the Catechism says. It says, The Church insistently urges everyone to prayer and to action so that the divine goodness may free us from the ancient bondage of war. And this is where the presumption against justice against war comes in. All citizens and all governments are obliged to work for the avoidance of war. Okay. Now that's different than pacifism. Yes. Presumption against war is different than, you know, war is never acceptable. Can never be justified in any instance. Exactly. We're certainly not condoning that. No, we're not. And that's not what the church is saying. But the church is saying we have to do everything we can to avoid war. And what it's saying implicitly is that... There are some instances where war cannot be avoided. It's almost like, I told this to John before the podcast, it's not that you choose to go to war, it's that you're left with no other choices but to go to war. Morally, it is the only option. Exactly. So that's the first one, just as a framework. And then you have the kind of the fundamental condition for just war is a just cause. You need a just cause to go to war. There's an injustice that has to be remedied. War is the only proper response. And this is what the Catechism says. It says, It says, The just cause can be this. The damage inflicted by the aggressor on the nation or community, so a nation attacks us or invades us or bombs us, the damage inflicted by the aggressor on the nation or community of nations must be lasting, grave, and certain. That's really important. Lasting, grave, and certain. Exactly. So in order to, just to draw an analogy, so... I'm trying to think of a war. So World War II, the attack on Pearl Harbor. There was a certain aggression from the Japanese to American soil. So it's a certain, it's grave, obviously, lives are being lost. And it's lasting. I mean, it's presuming that they're going to, this is a damage that's done that's going to be lasting, and it's presumed that they're going to keep coming with other attacks. We have the condition of last resort. So this is what the Catechism says, 2309. All other means of putting an end to it, the injustice, must have been shown to be impractical or ineffective. Okay. So basically anything else we try is not going to remedy this injustice. The only thing, the last resort, is we go to war. Like I said, we don't choose to go to war. We have to go to war. This is all when you're in war having right intention. Right. And then discrimination we talked about already, which is proportionality. You have to discriminate between soldiers and noncombatants. When it comes to the war in Iraq, which is the most interesting case and most kind of recent in our consciousness in America, I think the fundamental controversial conditions of going to war were the condition of last resort. Especially in what we have from the catechism now. War is always a response to an injustice already committed, or at least certainly. it's like the guy's coming at you with a knife. summarization.results: The discussions center around the concept of just war in Catholic teachings, emphasizing that war should only be pursued to address existing injustices. Various aspects of just war theory are explored, including the necessity of a just cause, last resort, probability of success, and proportionality. The controversy surrounding preemptive strikes, particularly in the context of the Iraq War, is highlighted. Additionally, the consequences of war, such as loss of life, displacement, and economic hardships, are discussed, along with the enduring presence of conflict and the importance of acknowledging and caring for those affected.
